segments.text: Okay.

The battalion commander, at the time I got there, I'd heard a report on the radio, you know, that that platoon was in trouble, and by the time I caught up with that brigade commander, the battalion commander, they were convinced that they'd been captured, both the battalion commander and the brigade commander, and they asked authority to pursue across the border
to recover them.
And I said, it's just not, no, you know, you can't do that.
But I told them also that I just couldn't believe, I couldn't reason, that any platoon of troopers in that division would surrender.
To me, it was out of the question.
There must be something else.
Well, sure enough, they were, of course,

something of an emotional state and I had full sympathy with them but here's one of those examples where they thought that just yonder a matter of hundreds of yards the enemy had their troops in captivity had been captured and taken away and we couldn't go get them that's how strict that policy was but anyway we did discover
Not one.
One man survived.
One man who played dead survived.
And they just walked into the trap.
Even had their, the normal, you know, security at work, but it just, they were just too close formation.
They got them.
But I've had many people ask me, why couldn't we win that war?
Yeah.
Why couldn't we destroy that enemy?
Well, let's take what I've just described, this division.
There were a number of them who really had everything back in the sanctuary except the troops he sent out to assemble for a fight.
It's just like standing behind a wall and
sticking the point of your spear through at somebody.
You can cut his spear off, head off, but he can draw back and put a new one on.
You can't get to him through that wall, and that's exactly the way it was.
Or another, anybody that's raising gardens like I am,
and has a problem with rabbits and rats, how does he get rid of them?
He's surely not going to get rid of them by killing them in his garden, you know.

But here we were with absolutely no authority to go across that border, and we had 600 miles plus of border that offered sanctuary to enemy troops, installations, and that very, very vital line of supply.
And any way you look at it, with an enemy who knew, and they had a very smart, very, very brilliant strategist in this, you know, Gap, you know, who was running this war.
And they never, and I came to resolve this in my own mind, they never intended to put more into South Vietnam than they could afford to lose.
And they would continue to put what they could afford to lose indefinitely.
And the strategy all along was, of course, to wear us out.
Sure.
On the other hand, it seems to be the only way.
And of course, having experienced this and looking back on it, it's a lot clearer now than it was at the time.
At the end of the first year, I didn't see how that enemy could continue to lose those people at the rate we were seeing them lost.
and continue the war.
By the end of the next six months, that was pretty, you know, becoming pretty clear.
He was sending in what he could afford to lose and that was it and he could go indefinitely.
So, we had to change or it was inevitable.
It seems to me that we'd have to quit.
Change in what ways?
Basically,
I felt that in the 1966 and 1967, well, what we had to do is change to an objective, a purpose that would conclude the war in our favor.
And clearly we had to get out of the boundaries of South Vietnam.
We had to get out with ground troops as well as air power and naval power.
And that was the basic change that would have had to occur.

Now, who can, however, to turn the coin over, who can criticize President Johnson, who had the final responsibility for this thing, from concluding that he could not, he must avoid at all costs, he must avoid getting the Chinese in that war.
President Johnson, I feel sure, must have had in the back of his mind that he had to limit that war to whatever extent was required to prevent the Chinese, to obviate the Chinese coming in.
Again, in retrospect, and I must say that there was some thought given to it at the time in the circles that I brainstormed with.
You'll recall that in 1966 and 1967, the Chinese were in the greatest disarray since they took over China in 1949.
The Cultural Revolution.
The Cultural Revolution.
I really think we could have gotten by with a great deal without bringing them into that war.
But the thing is, either enter the thing with the
plan and the strategy and the determination to win it or don't get in it.
And I don't think we'll do that again.
I don't think we'll go in again without a strategy to win.
The strategy used is credited to Secretary of Defense McNamara.
It was called the strategy of graduated response.
And I don't think we're going to have to wait two generations for historians to record it clearly as a stupid, unreasoned, inappropriate strategy for war.
And we were at war.
Why do you say that?
Why do you say it was stupid?
Well, the strategy was if the enemy hits you, you hit him back just a little harder.
So, if he hits back a little harder, you hit him just a little harder more.
Well, that's quite a departure from Sherman's old busties with the mosties, but what it does is violate the very clearly established principle of war of mass.
if you're going to engage the enemy, engage him with sufficient mass to overpower him at the earliest possible time.
In fact, those two principles of war, the objective and mass, were the two most violated in Vietnam that assured lack of success, in my opinion.
In other words, you would
blame the loss of Vietnam on the civilians?
No.
No, I didn't say that.
Well, you were talking about McNamara and Johnson.
No, I was talking about the fact I was referring to President Johnson's final responsibility, which presumably he had concluded that he wanted to be sure and avoid the Chinese.
Yeah.
And so, therefore, we went in on what's called, of course, a limited war, but without any real plan for winning it.
And the strategy really is attributed to that strategy of graduated response, limited war.
It was attributed to McNamara.
No, I think if you...

rather than say blame the civilians, I think that just as much blame, if not more, should go on our Joint Chiefs of Staff and senior commanders who didn't, should have had, of course, the sounder knowledge of what was required there and didn't sell it, didn't sell a better solution.
I think there's enough blame to go around, and I'm not discussing this to fix the blame, but I was trying to.
And again, in hindsight, all of this comes much more clearly, and the only benefit that we're going to gain from studying this war and finding where the failures were is to learn from it.
Sure.
Well, what's your opinion of Robert McNamara?
I think Mr. McNamara, of course, I never knew him personally, and I was always looking at him at considerable range, but obviously he was a brilliant man.
He had a great mentality, in other words.
He was a great organizer.
Unfortunately, in such detail that he had the Department of Defense doing what two echelons below should have been doing.
Great energy.
And he certainly had the strength of his convictions.
And he certainly could put them across to his president.
But I think that we, I hope, have learned that...
He over-organized the Office of the Secretary of Defense.
He exercised more decision on pure military matters than any civilian should undertake.
And in doing so, of course, he dominated.
He was very dominant in his goal.
And in my opinion,
He certainly should be given credit for his intelligence and his dedication and his effort, but he certainly also is to be criticized for, I think, hindering as much as he helped, if not more.
Hindering in what way?
Making all those decisions?
When the field commander should have done that?
We talked about 20 years to the field.

the Lance Missile, twenty years to field the computer system, fire direction system for the Army, the strategy of graduated response, the overall organization of the Defense Department requiring the processing and staffing and decision making there that should be made echelon below, and that's what I'm talking about.
Okay.
When you were

After you returned from Vietnam, did you ever get, I don't know if you remember, did you ever get a survey from another Brigadier General or a man who was a Brigadier General later in the war named Douglas Kennard?
I did.
I got a letter from him asking me to contribute by commenting on Commander General Westmoreland and various things, and I never participated.
Why not?
Oh, I didn't think that, I didn't know really what his purpose was in the first place.
And I felt if I were going to contribute to something like that, I ought to do it myself.
And I didn't think I had a lot to contribute.
I mean, after all, I was never in a position of tremendous responsibility.
I was not tested in the highest jobs.
To me, I put it in the same category of criticizing your commander when you don't actually do.
You don't think you ought to do that.
That's what he was looking for, was criticism.
If you got a balanced view from me about General Westmoreland, and I've said some things about General Westmoreland here, I'd have to put it in perspective.
And he would, I presume, expect that perspective to show weaknesses as well as strengths.
Well, as I said earlier, I don't think General Westmoreland
weaknesses showed through if you discount the fact that he didn't challenge his mission.
Well, I was just wondering because Kenner did write a book entitled The War Managers.
I haven't read that.

Which is two-thirds of the generals, there were about 160 generals in Vietnam during the time and two-thirds of them did respond to that survey and then he put it together in a book and I was just wondering.
Have you read the book?
Yeah.
Was it good?
I thought it was very interesting.

I'd like to read it, but the reason I didn't participate was I just, if I'd known him well, if General Kennard, my former commander, had asked for that information, knowing him, I would have given it to him.
I would have given him my opinion.
Now you were in, when you were in Vietnam, you were made general officer, brigadier general.
in August of 1966.
What were your feelings when you found out about that?
Well, I was very surprised, really, and gratified, of course.
And I was delighted.
You see, when I was nominated, I was asked to come up with General Kennard to be Assistant Division Commander immediately as Colonel.
So I was a Colonel, Assistant Division Commander, until they promoted those above me and got down to publishing my orders, those who'd been nominated.
You know, they're promoted over a period of a year.
And I never had a finer job than working with General Kennard on top of that division.

you take those things right I must say it a little bit a little bit more uh stirring than being promoted to colonel or the lieutenant colonel but they all all promotions are that way the next one looks better well then the next one came just about a year and a half which is incredible to in a year and a half to go from one star to two star general how can you account for that well I'm not sure that I could uh

I think again, being in the place I was in at the time I was there, I was in a very fortunate position as assistant division commander of that division, and I believe I was promoted strictly on that performance.
Because the next major general selection board that met, I was selected.
And of course I waited another period of time before I got
in line to actually receive my orders.
But I must judge that that was it.
Would you like to say anything else about your experiences in Vietnam before we leave?
I've covered the questions I want to cover.
Let's take a break now, and we'll resume later.
Okay.
I think when we talk of personalities in command in Vietnam, we did have a
We've talked about General Westmoreland.
We've talked about our division.

But in between General Westmoreland and our division was, in effect, a corps headquarters called Third Field Force, commanded by General Swede Larson, who incidentally was, I believe, a contemporary of General Westmoreland's.
And he was a lieutenant general, and he was commanding
our division and a couple of others in that 3rd Corps area.
And he was really a counterpart to the Vietnamese 3rd Corps.

And I might add that in the matter of using and working with the South Vietnamese, that was the level at which the South Vietnamese divisions and the U.S. divisions were coordinated, is at corps level, above our division level, you see.
And General Westmoreland, General Larson, of course we saw him often, and he was down in the train a long way off in distance, but of course we had good communication.
Those helicopters again came in very handy because he could get around to his divisions very reasonably that way.
But he was a very strong personality, although a quiet man.
And I think one of the finest commanders ever.
in Vietnam.
Naturally, he was our corps commander, and I saw more of him than I did the other corps commanders.
Why do you say he was one of the finest?
Because of the effectiveness with which he commanded.
I think it was a misfortune that he came home after his first year, came to the United States.
I'm going to get back to the press for a minute here.
And he was interviewed by the press, I believe in San Francisco.
He was about to depart to go back to Vietnam.
For a second tour?
To continue his tour.
He was just home on a brief stay.
And I can't even recall the details of the subject that was brought up, but a controversial subject was brought up.
And in his typical fashion, he very quietly and honestly
addressed the matter, which was his view was somewhat in conflict with that of the Secretary of Defense.
And he got in, I think, serious trouble over that.
And it's most unfortunate because it wasn't that big a thing.
Do you remember what it was about?
I don't recall.
It wasn't that important, you see.
It was just the fact that when he talked about it, he talked about it as he viewed it.
I always, I've mentioned this simply because I felt he had such capabilities that he was going to continue, probably be one of the very top officers in the Army when he left Vietnam.
But I believe he retired as a, I'm sure he retired as a lieutenant general.
And that one statement might have hindered his career?
I think it got him into
difficulties with the Secretary of Defense and the Secretary of Army.
Now that's not a matter of black and white because perhaps he shouldn't have opened his mouth, but once he did, you know, he told it like it was.
And it hadn't come out quite that way by an earlier statement out of the Office of the Secretary of Defense.
I'm over, we were saying too much about this, but I did want to mention that because I did expect, had such great respect for him, and did expect to see him with his fourth star.
And did General Arson stay on then?
He went back and completed his tour as a commander of third field force, or third, it was a corps command, really.
That was the designation for it, so we didn't conflict with
the core designation of the Vietnamese.
So, shall we leave Vietnam for a while?
Sure.
All right.
What were your feelings when you received orders to go back to the United States?
I was ready.
And when was it?
It was 1966.
Early 67.
Yeah, March of 67, I believe.
Okay, March of 1967, and where did you go?
Went to the Army Materiel Command headquarters in Washington.
As deputy director of research and laboratories.
As deputy director of research and laboratories and my first assignment to a logistics position.
In a sense, this was logistics, but it was really research and development.
My function

there and I was only there a brief time until I was promoted to major general and therefore that was a brigadier slot and I needed to be moved and General Kennard asked for me to come over to be his deputy commander.
You were only there for eight months?
That's right.
From April 67 to January 68?
That's right.
Then I moved over to be deputy as a major general to be deputy commander with General Kennard.
But that was an interesting eight months, I might add, and I can very briefly outline what the functions were.
One of my functions was to be commander of the seven independent laboratories of the Army Materiel Command, and that in itself was fascinating.
These are scientific laboratories dealing with basically applied research, but some basic research.
It's basic and applied research is what it was.
And each commanded by a colonel, each with a deputy civilian, and each, of course, with a different mission.
The other part- What were the missions?
Well, for example, they had a wide range of missions, from research and development on clothing and personal equipment up in Massachusetts, to cold weather research
in Alaska.
Then there was theoh, there was a laboratory at the Electronics Command.
There was a laboratory that was established in parallel with the Ordnance Center.
There was a laboratory in parallel to transportation and one for aviation and so forth.
And it had very highly educated and qualified scientists assigned there.
Both civilian and military?
Yes, the scientists were primarily civilian, but military command and some military officers.
And then the rest of my function was as deputy to the Army Materiel Command Director of Research and Development.
And, of course, that's just what the term implies.
And that had to do with supervision of the research and development effort throughout Army Materiel Command and the various subordinate commands.

You see, in the Army, the Army Materiel Command has been renamed, but its function was to take this stated requirement that, like we were speaking of when I was down at Fort Sill and the artillery combat developments set up,

And once that requirement is stated and approved, in other words, we, the artillerymen, need this kind of a weapon to do this job with, once that's approved, the Army Interior Low Command has the function of producing it.
And if there's more development required than there usually is, they get it done.
And then their final...
So I was operating in connection with that.
But their final responsibility is to produce it, or have it produced by contract.
So that's what that amounted to, and it was very interesting.
And there was one interesting incident occurred that kind of sidelined me from this for a while, for about three months.
There was a veryGeneral Besson was commanding.
General Frank Besson was commanding Army Materiel Command, and he used a system of what he called
He used project managers.

In other words, he would define an area that had to go through this process of research, development, manufacture, supplying, you know, resupplying, and so forth, and he'd turn it over to one officer to be responsible for it from the start to the end.
He was in charge of that whole project, and he theoretically had the authority of the commanding general with the other agencies
to get that job done.

And these people reported directly to him, and he had a fantastic capacity to assimilate and remember details of these various projects because he had a number of these project managers reporting directly to him.
He had a project manager who was in charge of producing on the very highest priority.
material for what was referred to as the McNamara Line in Vietnam, in which new types of sensors were developed by sensing sound or sensing motion, sensing light, to try to keep up with the movement
in critical areas of the enemy, particularly in the border areas.
And then there were involved also some exotic weapons, munitions, that could be automatically set off by sound or
stepping on them, you know, light weight, and so forth.
And this project office had the job of getting that done, and that was commanded by a colonel, headed by a colonel, and he had a heart attack, disabling heart attack.
And this project was tied right in with the Secretary of Defense's office with a very senior general running it for the Secretary of Defense.
It had the very highest priority, and we met
Anyway, I was appointed to jump in and take over this job until he could find another project manager.
And it was a fascinating experience because it involved this whole gamut of things to include procurement.
I'd never been involved in procurement in my life.
And I recall making a trip to a producer and actually contracting to buy a certain number of sensors on a handshake.
And that, I guess, was unheard of.
And we visualized volumes of paperwork to get a procurement order out and so forth and so on.
But in this case, it was done on a handshake and they went to work and the paperwork came later.
But that was because of the priority of Texas Instruments in Dallas, Texas.
It was because of the priorities of this project.
Well, of course, I think I was with it three months and I found it fascinating.
They found you another job.
But I left them to go to this other job.
And they found another colonel to take it over.
Tell me about this so-called McNamara line.
I've heard some things about this.
Was it ever in any way successful?
Let me say this.
The full array that would have made it successful I think was never finally fully completed.
I think it was useful, but to call it a success, I never saw that kind of evidence.
You know, call it completely successful.
And remember, we were really in the waning stages of that war, too.
This was in late 67.
No, we were still pretty active, yeah.
I guess it's fair to say that it was useful.
But the project was still carried on.
for a great length of time, and I think they're still building on those requirements.
And I think someday that it will be very significant.
One of the requirements, which we had not developed when I lost touch with it, is for a means of processing signals that you get from pre-positioned sensors.
And here is where you've got to tie in the computer.
So that requirement has to be finally met.
Then when you get the computer that can handle, and all this is being, I'm sure, still actively worked on.
After you get the computer then that can put the data together, the human mind has still got to make judgments.
So you've got to have the people
organized properly to assess all this information and see that a timely action is taken on it.
Really, we're talking about intelligence, of course.
Sure.
Intelligence gathering.
Intelligence gathering.
And it's not intelligence, of course, until it's processed.
Information gathering is what we're talking about.
But I think great strides are going to be made in this.
the computer's going to have an important part in it.
There's no question about it.
Even in Vietnam, before this was even tried, in our division, we could get more intelligence information than we could handle and process on a timely basis right there.
And the reason we got more, I thought, was one, there were several.
First, we concentrated on intelligence.
And if you concentrate on it, you'll get more.
but also we did have electronic intelligence, which helped a great deal.
Furthermore, we had all of these eyes in the sky all the time with these 400-plus aircraft, and it's tremendous the amount of detail that over a period of a day would come in just from observation.
Sure.
But anyway, you could see the need right there.

for better means of collating their stuff, you know, matching items up to produce conclusive intelligence or contributing intelligence that leads you to a conclusion that prompts you to act, and prompts you to act in time.
Did you work with the CIA and DIA at, I mean, did you have, for these few months, did you have close cooperation with these other agencies?
during this project work.
Actually, that was performed at OSD level, Secretary of Defense Office level.
During the Vietnam War, this wasn't- I remember that, and it wasn't a very large amount of time, but I remember that there was some discussion
about a McNamara wall to separate North and South Vietnam by some sort of atomic wall or nuclear or radiation wall or something.
Do you remember anything about that?
No, I really don't.
I'm not knowledgeable on that.
Of course, it was never put into place, but I just remember that in the press.
Okay.
Were there any other significant research and development projects going on?
Are you free to talk about those while you were?
Well, of course.
At that time, this was the exotic one that I became acquainted with.
But, of course, there's a constant effort.
Oh, sure.
As you can imagine.
I outlined just a few of the things that we were after in the field artillery 20 years ago.
Well, everybody else is trying to accomplish the same basic goals.
And it was a fascinating command.
Now, this command also, of course, was the big supply agency for the whole Army.
procurement and supply.
And it was the maintenance, the highest echelons of maintenance came under this command.

So, it would have been interesting to complete a two or three year tour there, but I was shunted to the Combat Development Command, which pleased me a great deal because General Kinnar was there and it was, I'd had a prior assignment in it and it was very interesting to me.
Okay, so you were there
in the Combat Developments Command, but from February 68 to November 68, not very long.
What did you do there for seven months?
I was the deputy commander, and I also functioned as chief of staff.
This was a staff organization, basically.
At that headquarters, we had the staff organization.
Then we had
various subordinate combat development command around the country.
We had, you might call it, it had its own name, but you might call it a tactical group or a combat unit grouping headquarters at Fort Leavenworth, Kansas.
at the Command General Staff College.
They supervised the combat development commands of the combat arms, which were generally located with their branch schools.
Then we had a similar group headquarters that oversaw the supply and service agencies, combat development agencies.
involved at Combat Development Headquarters with directing all of these people in this area that I mentioned earlier.
How should we be organized in the Army?
How should we fight?
How should we be equipped, and how should we fight?
And we determined the answer to those questions in the form of requirements for the development
tables of organization, new equipments, new weapons, new systems, and new doctrine.
And that was the mission of that organization.
Now, I wasn't there very long because Well, why weren't youwhy were you only there for seven months?
Because the chief staff, General Westmoreland, said that he wanted me to be his chiefthe chief legislative liaison for the Army.
And I'm chuckling because I didn't want to leave.
I was very happy where I was.
I'd just really gotten my teeth into my work there.
I liked working for General Kennard, and so I didn't want to go.
He reclaimed it for me.
I don't know that he got in trouble, but I know he got fussed after resisting.
But anyway, I went up there.
Chief of Legislative Liaison after seven months in this command, and I finished my Army career as Chief of Legislative Liaison.
Well, this is your last job.
Let's talk about this.
This is one of the most important jobs, at least politically, that you ever had.
Did you like it?
I liked it very much.
I really did.
I found it worthy of anyone's application and effort.
It's a unique job in the Army that none other liked.
The function was to work with the Congress for the Army, and the business we had with the Congress included several things.
First of all, of course, it was our legislation, the most important of which was our budget.
Sure, absolutely.
And, of course, that budget includes money for all these things we're talking about, not only operating and maintaining what we've got, but developing these new things and procuring them.
And, of course, legislation included special legislation or non-routine legislation, such as, well, you'd be interested, for example, what would be such things as a GI Bill or pay legislation or...
authorizations for strength of the Army, such things as the ratio of officers in various grades to soldiers or to the strength of the Army, all sorts of things.
Anything that has to be legislated.
That's right.
And so we were the funnel out of the Army and back through to the Army staff on this.
And how many people did you have?
I had a few over 100 people.
Gee whiz.
Now, you'll understand this, why we had that many when I finished the functions.
Another function was to handle the correspondence between the Army and the Congress.
In other words, if Private John Doe in Vietnam writes his congressman and says, I was supposed to go home a month ago, and I don't have my orders yet.
I mean, he's just exasperated.
Anything from that
on up to such things as the Ryden Hoover letter about me lying.
That comes to my office.
I forget the figures, but I think we handled 1,500 letters a week to the Congress on everything you can imagine.
Congressmen inquiring for their own edification for information, data,
or individuals in the Army writing their congressman, which happens frequently, and that's their right, and that's all right.
Another function of that office was to handle congressional investigations that affected the Army.
In other words, be the contact in the Army for congressional investigations.
It was my duty to handle several items of bad news during my tour there, because this
This was a very abnormal period in Army history, in my opinion.
During my tour as Chief Legislative Liaison, this disenchantment with Vietnam was growing in the minds of the people.
And, of course, Congress truly is a reflection of the people.
And I think that's what it's intended to be.
For example, we had the My Lai thing.
which was a tremendous investigation.
We had the...
Which you subsequently handed over to the Inspector General.
Well, yes, but we still...
The Congress started its own investigation, you know.
Sure.
So you worked with them.
So I worked with them and had to coordinate with the Army and follow them both.
Then you might recall we had...
The matter of the senior non-commissioned officer taking kickbacks from clubs and so forth.
Even the former sergeant major of the Army was involved.
And then we had the case... What happened to him?
He was court-martialed.
Then we had the case of the... And this was in Vietnam, wasn't it?
That he was taking the kickbacks of Vietnam.
And he was running, I remember.
It also had occurred in Europe.
And the same people were, the same non-coms were involved at different times.
And then we had the case of the Major General, former Provo Marshal General of the Army, being investigated for accepting rare weapons as contributions
In other words, sort of not for the Army, but...
Personal.
Personal, but because he was who he was, and then selling them.
Oh, selling them, too?
Trading in them and selling them.
And what happened to him?
I don't recall, but he got his just desserts.
Then we had a case of a brigadier general whom I knew who was accused of...

frauds and the PX system in Europe and in Vietnam and he was found these are congressional investigations now yeah right anytime the Congress starts an investigation the army has to parallel it to keep them you know to provide them what the information they need from us and did you direct and and quite and also the reverse sure did you direct the investigations or did you leave that to
To the IG?
No, no.
The investigations were always directed by the Inspector General or the Chief Staff's Office.
You see, I worked directly...
So you worked between them.
Yes, I was a coordinator with the Congress, in and out of the Congress.
Now, I remember my direct boss was the Secretary of the Army.
Who was at that time?
Secretary Stanley Reaser, a very fine one.
Secretary Reaser, yeah.
who later became the negotiator in SALT talks and he later became Deputy Secretary of Defense.
But my function said I would be responsible to the Secretary of the Army and responsive to the Chief of Staff.
So I really had two bosses.
Do you have some other examples of some of the congressional investigations?
Those were the significant ones.
Okay, fine.
And they were all painful ones for the Army, because they were all bad news.
Yeah.
Which, of course, brings the next question.
From 68 to 70, America, especially the youth in America, are turning against the war in Vietnam, and there's an increasing...
